WRITING.TEXT: From my knowledge the burning at the bottom of the pan is due to having too little liquid. Tho it could be that the Garlic burnt and made a sour taste too, But this is unlikely since you said the pork was resting on it. In my opinion you should have added water with the white wine so you would have a decent amount of liquid at the bottom of the pan, if you have too much liquid at the end you could always reduce it to intensify the flavor to your liking.
Amazing ! Good job OP

That sounds Great! The only difference is that I cooked the Salmon skin side down until 3/4 done, This gives the skin more time to crisp up. It's also very important to have medium heat because if its's too hot the skin will scorch and not caramelize.
Instead of butter I used olive oil and seasoned with salt and Dill.
In your method of cooking, does the skin turn out extremely crispy ? Because I am thinking that it will remain slightly soft and that is not pleasant to eat in my opinion.

I am not exactly sure which type of salmon it was, The fish monger did not specify. But I am sure that you can do this with Norwegian Salmon as the restaurant I work in has Norwegian Salmon and that is how we serve it.
How did the Chef prepare the salmon ?
Did you let it rest before slicing it up ? It looks like it lost way too much of it's tasty juices to the plate. Great Job though! love the Farm to table aspect and the plating is nice :)
Yeah it's got a Ton of Fat !
Got it From my local butcher ! ext time I think I would prefer to have it without ribs, Just for presentation purposes though
It makes me sad too, so many times!! Thank you for the compliment, much appreciated.

The Salmon Skin is not really tough, When cooked like this it is very crispy and yes I did eat it. It's tastyyyy

Cooked the Salmon skin side down until 3/4 ready on medium heat (Important that the pan is not too hot when you place the salmon). Brushed the salmon with olive oil before cooking and added some more to the pan. Don't know about the timing, but its easy to tell when salmon is 3/4 cooked because you can tell by the colour change.
Never tried smoking belly, only smoked the shoulder and butt

I added a vinaigrette to the Crushed potato and also on the salmon once placed on the potato.

Got The idea mainly from Gordon Ramsay's Crispy Salmon video but tweaked it to my liking. Added Dill to the Salmon before cooking. Added Mint to the potatoes and I also made my own vinaigrette to complement the changes I made in the dish.

WRITING.TEXT:
Buy a good piece of pork belly, Score the skin, season the skin.
Pre heat oven at 160 celsius, put in room temperature pork and cook for 2.5-3 hours (If skin is not crispy put heat up to 200 with fan for the last 30 mins).
For this particular recipe I followed Marco Pierre White's video on youtube. You could find it easily

WRITING.TEXT: Looks good ! , but i don't know about mixing the pesto and tomato bacon jam. Does the pesto go well with the tomato bacon jam ?
Amazing plating ! wonderful idea ! Good job :)
Of course its thing... Google it
like 7 euros per burger
not really, Balance is key.

Quite simple, Buy that blend of meat and mix it together. Make the tomato relish, you can find hundreds of recipes for it.
Fry the patties and bacon. When the patties are nearly done put the vintage cheddar pieces on so that they melt. Then put patties to the side to rest and toast the bun. Once toasted assemble everything.
Google tomato relish and ketchup and tell me if they are the same.

Same goes for this comment.. I didn't make up 'Vintage' it's a type of cheddar such as mild or mature cheddar. Vintage cheddar is aged for about 24 months making it a very sharp cheddar. If u've never tried it, go get some.. The taste is totally different from normal cheddar.

Can't believe you got 22 up votes for that comment without any one explaining what tomato relish is... It's a combination of garlic onion and tomato simmered in vinegar and brown sugar, making it sweet and acidic.
Homemade

WRITING.TEXT: I did add more sauce, Just drizzled it in that way fr presentation.
Garlic was added to the sauce and the filling. I used the garlic that was braising with the beef.

Yep, The pasta was a little under cooked, The problem is that i needed to make the dough thinner, that way it would have cooked more evenly ! but it was my first time ever making the dough and forming the ravioli, Quite pleased anyway :)
The sauce is what the beef ribs were braising in. It consisted of red wine and beef broth. I reduced the sauce down and added cream to reduce the richness just abit and add more texture.
True that, but i wanted to try something new

Trust me their was no need for any Gorgonzola on top (although it sounds interesting), the flavor profile was already amazing as is, trust me.
I chose to just put parsley on top to cut through the richness of the sauce at times. The lemon zest i think would have been a good idea, but the garlic i would leave out, only because i used the garlic that i braised the beef ribs in with the sauce and the filling.
Truely appreciated that you noticed that a lot of time and effort was taken to produce this dish. Thank you so much for the ideas and compliments !
P.S I did add much more sauce, that amount was just for presentation :D
I firstly seared the ribs in olive oil then braised them in red wine, tomato paste and garlic for 2.5hrs in the oven at 170 degrees celsius.

WRITING.TEXT:
I really don't agree with the above point you have made. Muscle does have exceptional flavour. One of the most expensive cuts of beef for example is the filet Mignon, which is a very lean meat and has superb taste.
I totally agree that fat enhances the flavor and makes a big part of it. but it's wrong to think that muscle has no flavor.
As pedazzle stated, Udon are a type of Japanese noodles.

Thank you for the information !! The main reason I post my pictures here is to get feedback from people and improve and try new things.
Would you be kind enough to give me a recipe or a link to find the authentic chicken satay you are mentioning ? I would mainly like to see what ingredients the sauce and marinade contain.

I Find it difficult to believe that you found a marbled chicken breast, I have never heard of such a thing. Plus the chicken breast is an extremely lean part of the chicken.
In any other type of meat (Pork, Veal, Lamb, Game animals) it would be great to find a marbled piece of meat as this keeps the piece of meat juicier once cooked.
Marbling is just intramuscular fat (fat deposited into the muscle's) which when cooked it melts making the meat tastier and juicier.
Hope this helps !
Marinated it in a Satay mixture then grilled it on the BBQ to perfection :) (Crispy AF on the outside and tender and Juicy in the middle)

Yep :) everything from scratch. I followed the below recipe and adjusted accordingly
http://cafedelites.com/2016/04/20/easy-thai-satay-chicken-recipe/

I preferred not to cook the chicken on skewers because since the chicken is cut into smaller pieces it dries out quicker once cooked. A whole boneless drumstick retains more juices.
I did marinade it for at least an hour in the below ingredients.
4 tablespoons coconut milk (from a 400ml tin) 1 tablespoons creamy peanut butter 1 tablespoon packed light brown sugar 1 tablespoon Thai red curry paste 1 tablespoon soy sauce 1 tablespoon fish sauce Pinch of salt 4 skinless chicken thighs, bone-in
Thank you :)
That's the Satay sauce
Yep Thai chicken satay, Chose to use boneless drumsticks instead of chicken breast on a skewer just for the fact that I find it juicier and tastier.
Thank you :)

Hey :) I used the below recipe as a base to follow the chicken satay sauce and marinade for the chicken, then I just added the Udon noodles with the sauce. I also tweaked the recipe a little were i deemed fit.
I'm not from the Western part of the world, and that is an authentic Thai Chicken Satay recipe, just because i didn't completely coat it doesn't mean its just peanut butter on chicken.
The chicken was marinated in Satay mixture and then I drizzled The satay sauce that i made onto it. I guess that qualifies as Satay.
This recipe is a Thai Chicken Satay which uses all the above ingredients. it might not look like satay just because i did not drench the chicken in the sauce. I'm From Malta :)

Yep used beschamel to make it creamier because the pesto itself would not be enough sauce.
Make pesto (Garlic,basil,Chilli, Parmesan,olive oil, pine nuts) Fried the chorizo and pancetta and removed the excess fat. Fried onions. Then I just layered everything out. Pesto,chorizo, pancetta, tomatoes, onions, beschamel, lasagna sheets
It's quite fatty i must admit ! but trust me, it's the best

Make pesto (Garlic,basil,Chilli, Parmesan,olive oil, pine nuts)
Fried the chorizo and pancetta and removed the excess fat.
Fried onions.
Then I just layered everything out. Pesto,chorizo, pancetta, tomatoes, onions, beschamel, lasagna sheets
Do it ! I'm sure you'll love it
Parmesan pairs best with pesto, plus i used mozzarella to have that string and added bite :) It was out of this world ! everybody that tried it was amazed haha

two big handfuls of fresh basil. 3 garlic cloves. around 200-300 g Parmesan cheese. fresh chilli 1 pack of pine nuts, roasted Added olive oil to desired consistency.

WRITING.TEXT: Something that is easy to do doesn't mean it has no skill, Doing something simple in the perfect way is better than doing something complicated and bad... I chose post the picture because i was proud with the outcome, In my opinion the ribs were not overcooked, when slow cooked that's just the way i like them.
yep

Were did i mention liquid smoke ? I never used liquid smoke, I used Smoky bbq sauce. If you don't like slow cookers i respect your opinion, But it definitely is a good way of cooking and making things as tender as you'd like :)
yeah of course you can. But i highly recommend you go buy some beef ribs and try this ! The would make a hugeeee difference in taste
I put a whole onion into the slow cooker, you could say it's caramelized haha
Just some smoked paprika
yep, used one medium sized onion
That's the way i like my ribs, tender as can be. Plus in a slow cooker cooking them to this point lets even more of the sauce to be absorbed into the meat. And yes the beefy goodness was still there.
Spot on
They are USDA Beef back ribs, split in half
Must invest in a better camera !
Definitely would taste better, I'm thinking of doing exactly what you said but instead of an oven i'l put them in a smoker for added smoky flavor :D

One of the best ways is in a slow cooker, Best way to cook ribs is in a smoker low and slow. Ribs should always be cooked low and slow.
That's my opinion of course :)
You should !! it was amazing :)
Yep, straight out of the slow cooker, no searing or any other form of cooking done.
I'm not exactly sure what temperature it maintains at low setting, but yes its an electric slow cooker.
no liquid at all, The only liquids i had were the BBQ sauce and honey

I used 2 large beef back ribs (approximately 600g), 2tbsp honey, half a bottle of smokey garlic bbq sauce (4-5 tbsp) 1 tsp cayenne 1tsp fennel seeds 1tsp mustard powder 1 medium sized onion sliced pinch of salt and pepper
Shuved all the above in the slow cooker, gave it a good mix and switched it on low.
Switched it off after around 7.5hrs and left them in the slow cooker with the lid on so that they keep cooking a little longer until they cool down and ready to serve
That would definitely make a big difference in the garlicky taste ! thanks for the tip

Put the beef ribs in a slow cooker with smokey garlic BBQ sauce, honey, mustard powder, cayenne pepper, salt, fennel seeds and a chopped onion. Cooked it on low for 8 hours.
The potato mash is quite simple, just added raw garlic and grated Parmesan cheese to the mixture of normal mashed potatoes (butter, cream etc)
It was amazing !!

WRITING.TEXT: Stir an egg in around 350G of chicken mince with some salt and pepper. Chop up some ham and cheese, Form chicken mince into a patty and fill with cheese and ham, Coat them in flour and breadcrumbs then fry. Then just fry an egg, fry some bacon and caramelize some onions. Then assemble with mayo, mustard and ketchup.
Not quite sure what the bun is exactly, but I buy it from a local baker. All his bread is flaky and soft

WRITING.TEXT: not at all, you cant really taste the brine, it mainly just keeps the chicken moist
Yeah pickle brined, Got a big jar of pickles put the brine in a big bowl then soaked the chicken pieces in it for around 24 hours. This helps the chicken retain more moisture after being fried.
Just saw it and i probably will in the coming days ! I followed matty matheson's recipe for this fried chicken (youtube video)

WRITING.TITLE: Pickle brined, buttermilk soaked; Fried Chicken, Honey Paprika glazed corn on the cob with a blue cheese dipping Sauce

WRITING.TEXT: To be honest with you I personally prefer a burger to be cooked medium-well, anything below that point is not considered the "perfect burger" for me, This was another test run at trying a medium rare burger instead of my usual preference of medium well, It was the conclusion for me that i would no longer cook it less than medium well. The meat looks so red just because of the lighting and angle of the camera, plus i had let the patty rest which distributed the juices through the whole patty giving it more of a reddish colour
The acidity in the balsamic glaze does neutralize the sweetness slighty but Blue cheese would have definitely been a great / better idea !!

WRITING.TITLE: 50% Chuck 50% Brisket patty, Fried mozarella, caramelized peach and Balsamic Glaze burger.

WRITING.TEXT:
Hi :) I mainly followed this recipe (link below) but made minor adjustments to my liking.
http://cafedelites.com/2016/04/20/easy-thai-satay-chicken-recipe/
That's called the bark and trust me its amazing !

Quite easy to cook if you got a smoker, All you need to do is rub them in salt and pepper (or your prefered rub). put ribs in smoker and maintain heat at 275-280 until tender and with a nice bark (6hrs or abit more) and trust me they are the tastiest thing ive ever smoked !
Thanks :)
Hey :) I smoked these ribs for 6 hours at 275 - 280 Fahrenheit. Rubbed the ribs with only salt and pepper (Texas style). Ohh and I smoked them on a weber 57cm kettle grill.

WRITING.TITLE: Hickory smoked Texas style Beef Back Ribs

WRITING.TEXT:
I do agreed with you to a certain point, But I hot smoked it (their are 2 types of smoking, hot smoking and cold smoking)
With hot smoking the cheese will not take a tremendous amount of smoke since it will smoke for no longer than 45 minutes to 1 hour, which would leave the Brie melted with a nice layer of smoke at the top.

WRITING.TITLE: Barbecued Chicken marinated in Satay mixture on some Udon noodles and drizzled with homemade Satay Sauce [2448x2448] [OC]

WRITING.TEXT: Brie is great, smoky flavour is great. So why not combine ? plus i love experimenting
I hot Smoked it for around 45 minutes to an hour at 250 Fahrenheit, I also shaved the top part of the cheese so it could absorb more smoke and added some chilli, paprica and cumin on top. :)
